The intensity of a stimulus is coded not by the amplitude of individual action potentials but by the frequency of firing (rate coding) and the number of neurons activated

Agonists & Antagonists: An agonist is a substance that mimics or enhances the action of a neurotransmitter (e.g., nicotine is an acetylcholine agonist; morphine is an endorphin agonist). An antagonist blocks or reduces the action of a neurotransmitter (e.g., curare blocks acetylcholine receptors; naloxone blocks opioid receptors). Reuptake inhibitors (e.g., SSRIs for serotonin) block the transporter that removes the neurotransmitter from the synaptic cleft, effectively increasing its availability and prolonging its action

Saltatory Conduction: Saltatory conduction refers to the "jumping" of action potentials from one node of Ranvier to the next along myelinated axons. This dramatically increases conduction velocity (up to 120 m/s in large myelinated fibers) compared to continuous conduction in unmyelinated fibers (~1-2 m/s). Demyelinating diseases such as multiple sclerosis disrupt saltatory conduction, slowing or blocking neural transmission

The neuron is the fundamental signaling unit of the nervous system. Although neurons vary widely in shape and size, they share a common structural plan consisting of a cell body, dendrites, and an axon

The resting potential of a neuron is approximately -70 mV , maintained by the sodium-potassium pump (3 Na+ out, 2 K+ in) and selective ion channel permeability. When excitatory inputs depolarize the membrane to the threshold (approximately -55 mV), an action potential is triggered

The absolute refractory period occurs during depolarization and early repolarization, when no stimulus (regardless of intensity) can trigger another action potential. The relative refractory period follows, during which a stronger-than-normal stimulus can trigger an action potential. These periods limit the maximum firing rate and ensure unidirectional propagation of the signal along the axon

Communication between neurons occurs at the synapse , the junction between a presynaptic terminal button and a postsynaptic dendrite (or cell body). The synaptic cleft — a gap of approximately 20-40 nanometers — separates the pre- and postsynaptic membranes. The sequence of synaptic transmission is as follows:

Behavioral genetics investigates the relative contributions of genetic and environmental factors to individual differences in behavior, cognition, and psychopathology. This field provides essential evidence for understanding the biological bases of psychological traits and disorders, and its concepts are heavily tested on the EPPP

Twin studies are the cornerstone method of behavioral genetics. They compare concordance rates (or correlations) between monozygotic (MZ, identical) twins, who share 100% of their DNA, and dizygotic (DZ, fraternal) twins, who share approximately 50% of their segregating genes

Adoption studies separate genetic from environmental contributions by comparing adopted children to both their biological parents (who share genes but not environment) and their adoptive parents (who share environment but not genes). If adopted children more closely resemble their biological parents on a trait, genetic factors are implicated. If they more closely resemble their adoptive parents, environmental factors are implicated. Adoption studies of schizophrenia  provided pivotal evidence for a genetic contribution to the disorder

Memory Consolidation: Consolidation is the process by which newly encoded, fragile memory traces are stabilized and integrated into long-term storage. Synaptic consolidation occurs within hours at the level of individual synapses (involving protein synthesis and structural changes). Systems consolidation occurs over weeks to years, involving the gradual transfer of memory representations from the hippocampus to distributed neocortical networks. Once fully consolidated, memories can be retrieved independently of the hippocampus

Clinical Features of Korsakoff's Syndrome: The hallmark features include severe anterograde amnesia, variable retrograde amnesia, and confabulation — the production of fabricated, distorted, or misinterpreted memories without the conscious intention to deceive. Confabulation occurs because the patient fills memory gaps with plausible-sounding but inaccurate information. Patients may also show apathy, lack of insight (anosognosia), and difficulty with temporal ordering of events. Procedural memory and priming are typically preserved

Hebb's Rule: Donald Hebb (1949) proposed that "cells that fire together wire together" — when a presynaptic neuron repeatedly contributes to firing a postsynaptic neuron, the synaptic connection between them is strengthened. This Hebbian learning rule anticipated the discovery of LTP by over two decades and remains a foundational principle of neural plasticity and memory formation. Hebb also proposed the concept of the "cell assembly" — a network of interconnected neurons that represents a memory and becomes increasingly coordinated through repeated co-activation

Clinical Application — Memory Reconsolidation in Therapy: Reconsolidation theory has informed trauma therapies that aim to reactivate traumatic memories in safe therapeutic conditions, then introduce new, corrective information during the reconsolidation window. This may update the original memory trace rather than simply creating a competing inhibitory memory (as in standard extinction). The approach is still being researched but represents a promising integration of neuroscience and psychotherapy

EPPP Distinction: Wernicke's encephalopathy (acute phase: confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia) and Korsakoff's syndrome (chronic phase: amnesia, confabulation) are often considered a continuum — Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome . Wernicke's is treated emergently with IV thiamine; if untreated, approximately 80% of cases progress to Korsakoff's, which is largely irreversible. The EPPP tests the connection between chronic alcohol use, thiamine deficiency, and the specific memory symptoms of Korsakoff's

The hippocampus , a seahorse-shaped structure in the medial temporal lobe, plays a critical role in the consolidation of new declarative (explicit) memories. It serves as a temporary indexing system that binds together distributed cortical representations of an experience, enabling the gradual transfer of memories to neocortical storage over time

The hippocampus is essential for encoding new episodic memories and spatial navigation (containing "place cells" that fire when an organism occupies a specific location). It is also part of the Papez circuit, which links the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, anterior thalamus, and cingulate cortex in a circuit important for memory formation

The case of H.M. (Henry Molaison, 1926-2008) is the most important single case in the history of memory neuroscience. In 1953, neurosurgeon William Beecher Scoville performed a bilateral medial temporal lobectomy (removing the hippocampus, amygdala, and surrounding cortex bilaterally) to treat H.M.'s severe epilepsy. The surgery controlled his seizures but produced profound amnesia

Korsakoff's syndrome is a chronic neurological condition caused by severe thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency , most commonly associated with chronic alcohol use disorder. The thiamine deficiency produces damage to the mammillary bodies, dorsomedial thalamus, and periventricular regions — all structures critical to memory circuits

Long-term potentiation (LTP) is the persistent strengthening of synaptic connections following high-frequency stimulation. First described in the hippocampus by Bliss and Lomo (1973), LTP is widely considered the primary cellular mechanism underlying learning and memory

LTP involves several key molecular steps: (1) high-frequency stimulation of the presynaptic neuron releases glutamate, (2) this activates AMPA and NMDA receptors on the postsynaptic neuron, (3) NMDA receptor activation (which requires both glutamate binding and sufficient postsynaptic depolarization) allows calcium influx, (4) calcium triggers intracellular signaling cascades that strengthen the synapse through insertion of additional AMPA receptors and, eventually, structural changes (new dendritic spines)

The amygdala modulates the encoding and consolidation of emotionally arousing memories. It does not store the declarative content of emotional memories but enhances hippocampal consolidation through stress hormone and norepinephrine signaling. This explains why emotionally charged events are generally better remembered — the amygdala amplifies the hippocampal encoding process. Amygdala damage impairs the emotional enhancement of memory without affecting the formation of non-emotional declarative memories

The cerebellum is essential for motor learning, classical conditioning of motor responses (e.g., eyeblink conditioning), and the fine-tuning of skilled movements. Cerebellar damage impairs the acquisition of conditioned motor responses and the performance of skilled procedural tasks

The basal ganglia (particularly the striatum) are critical for habit learning, stimulus-response associations, and the automatization of behaviors through reinforcement. Patients with Huntington's disease (caudate nucleus atrophy) or Parkinson's disease (substantia nigra degeneration) show impaired procedural and habit learning despite relatively preserved declarative memory in early stages

Reconsolidation theory proposes that when a consolidated memory is reactivated (retrieved), it temporarily returns to a labile state and must be reconsolidated to persist. During this reconsolidation window, the memory is vulnerable to modification, disruption, or updating. This has clinical implications for treating PTSD — reactivating a traumatic memory during a therapeutic window (e.g., with propranolol administration or extinction training) may allow the emotional component to be weakened during reconsolidation

passages.section: Recall, Recognition & the Serial Position Effect
passages.passage: Serial Position Effect: The serial position effect describes the tendency to recall items at the beginning and end of a list better than items in the middle. The primacy effect (superior recall of early items) is attributed to greater rehearsal and transfer to long-term memory. The recency effect (superior recall of recent items) is attributed to the items still being active in short-term/working memory. A distractor task between learning and recall eliminates the recency effect but not the primacy effect, supporting the distinction between STM and LTM stores

Misinformation Effect: The misinformation effect occurs when misleading post-event information is incorporated into an individual's memory of the original event. This can take the form of misleading questions, exposure to inaccurate accounts from other witnesses, or suggestive therapeutic techniques. The misinformation effect is more powerful when the original memory is weak, when the misleading information is presented with authority, and when there is a long delay between the event and the misinformation

Clinical Relevance: Proactive interference increases with age and is a significant contributor to age-related memory complaints. Older adults are particularly susceptible to proactive interference because they have accumulated more competing memories and may have reduced inhibitory control. In neuropsychological testing, proactive interference is assessed through paradigms such as the release-from-PI procedure and is a sensitive indicator of frontal lobe dysfunction

passages.section: Recall, Recognition & the Serial Position Effect
passages.passage: EPPP Application: If an EPPP question describes a participant who learns a word list, performs 30 seconds of mental arithmetic, and then recalls the list, the expected finding is that the primacy effect is preserved (early items still recalled well) but the recency effect is eliminated (recent items are no longer in STM). This classic finding supports the Atkinson-Shiffrin dual-store model

passages.section: Recall, Recognition & the Serial Position Effect
passages.passage: Retrieval processes vary in the amount of environmental support they provide. Recall requires generating information from memory with minimal cues (e.g., "Name the four lobes of the cortex"), while recognition requires identifying previously encountered information from a set of alternatives (e.g., multiple-choice questions). Recognition is generally easier because the correct answer serves as its own retrieval cue

passages.section: The Ebbinghaus Forgetting Curve & Interference Theory
passages.passage: Hermann Ebbinghaus (1885) conducted the first systematic study of forgetting using nonsense syllables. His forgetting curve demonstrated that forgetting is most rapid immediately after learning, with the rate of forgetting decelerating over time. Approximately 50% of newly learned material is forgotten within the first hour, and about 70% within 24 hours, but the remaining material is retained relatively stably over longer periods
Interference theory proposes that forgetting occurs because memories compete with one another during retrieval. Two forms of interference are critical for the EPPP:

Cue-dependent forgetting occurs when information is stored in long-term memory but cannot be accessed because the appropriate retrieval cues are absent. This is distinct from trace decay — the memory exists but is temporarily inaccessible. The tip-of-the-tongue (TOT) phenomenon is a vivid example: the person feels certain they know the word, can often recall partial information (first letter, number of syllables), but cannot produce the complete word until the right cue appears

Elizabeth Loftus's research on the misinformation effect demonstrates that post-event information can alter memory for the original event. In her classic studies, participants who watched a video of a car accident and were later asked "How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?" (vs. "contacted" or "hit") reported higher speed estimates and were more likely to falsely remember seeing broken glass

The Deese-Roediger-McDermott (DRM) paradigm demonstrates spontaneous false memory formation. Participants study a list of words all related to a non-presented critical lure (e.g., "bed," "rest," "awake," "tired," "dream" — the critical lure being "sleep"). At test, participants frequently recall or recognize the critical lure with high confidence, sometimes claiming to remember specific details of its presentation. This demonstrates that semantic activation during encoding can create false memories that feel phenomenologically real

Source monitoring refers to the process of attributing a memory to its correct source. Source monitoring errors occur when individuals correctly remember information but misattribute its origin — confusing something they imagined with something they actually experienced, something they read with something someone told them, or something one person said with something another person said. These errors are particularly common in children, older adults, and individuals with frontal lobe dysfunction

The recovered memory debate centers on whether traumatic memories can be repressed and later accurately recovered, or whether "recovered" memories are typically false memories created through suggestive therapeutic techniques

Motivated forgetting refers to the concept that individuals may forget information because it is unpleasant, threatening, or anxiety-provoking. Freud's concept of repression posits that traumatic memories are actively pushed out of conscious awareness as a defense mechanism. While there is evidence for intentional suppression of unwanted memories (Anderson & Green's "Think/No-Think" paradigm), the scientific evidence for Freudian repression of entire traumatic events is weak and contested

Absolute Threshold: The absolute threshold is the minimum intensity of a stimulus that can be detected 50% of the time. For example, the absolute threshold for vision is roughly the equivalent of a candle flame visible from 30 miles on a clear dark night. Note that the 50% criterion is key — detection is probabilistic, not all-or-none

Difference Threshold (JND): The difference threshold , or just noticeable difference (JND) , is the minimum difference between two stimuli that can be detected 50% of the time. Weber's Law states that the JND is a constant proportion of the original stimulus intensity (delta I / I = k). For example, if you can just barely notice the difference between a 100g weight and a 102g weight (2% difference), you would need a 4g difference to detect a change from 200g. The Weber fraction (k) is smaller for more sensitive modalities

Trichromatic Theory (Young-Helmholtz): The retina contains three types of cones, each maximally sensitive to a different wavelength: short (blue), medium (green), and long (red). All perceived colors result from the combined activation of these three cone types. This theory explains color mixing and certain forms of color blindness (e.g., dichromacy from the absence of one cone type)

Bottom-Up vs. Top-Down Processing: Bottom-up processing (data-driven) begins with sensory input and builds up to perception without influence from prior knowledge. Top-down processing (concept-driven) uses prior knowledge, expectations, and context to interpret sensory input. Most perception involves an interaction of both. Top-down processing explains why context allows you to read words with missing letters, why ambiguous stimuli are perceived differently depending on expectations, and why cultural background influences perception

Clinical Relevance: Attentional deficits are a core feature of many psychological disorders tested on the EPPP. ADHD involves impairments in sustained attention and executive control of attention. Hemispatial neglect following right parietal stroke represents a dramatic failure of spatial attention (Posner's disengage operation). Anxiety disorders involve attentional bias toward threat-related stimuli, which can be measured with the dot-probe task. Understanding the theoretical models of attention provides the conceptual framework for understanding these clinical presentations

Clinical Application: Signal detection theory applies directly to clinical decision-making. A psychologist conducting a risk assessment must balance the cost of false positives (incorrectly identifying someone as dangerous, leading to unnecessary restriction) against the cost of false negatives (failing to identify a truly dangerous individual). The base rate of the behavior, the severity of consequences, and the clinician's threshold for action all influence the decision criterion
Psychophysics is the study of the relationship between physical stimuli and the psychological sensations they produce. Several foundational concepts from psychophysics are heavily tested on the EPPP

Signal detection theory provides a framework for understanding how decisions are made under conditions of uncertainty, going beyond simple threshold concepts by acknowledging that detection depends on both the sensitivity of the observer and their response criterion (decision bias)

The observer's sensitivity (d-prime) reflects their ability to discriminate signal from noise, independent of response bias. The response criterion (beta) reflects the observer's willingness to say "yes" — a liberal criterion produces more hits but also more false alarms, while a conservative criterion produces fewer false alarms but also more misses. Response criterion shifts depending on the payoff matrix (e.g., a radiologist screening for cancer should adopt a liberal criterion because missing a tumor [miss] is more costly than a false alarm)

Sensory adaptation is the diminished sensitivity to an unchanging stimulus over time. When you first enter a room with a strong odor, the smell is noticeable, but after several minutes, you barely detect it. This occurs because sensory receptors reduce their firing rate in response to constant stimulation. Importantly, pain receptors show minimal adaptation — a biologically adaptive feature that ensures continued attention to potentially harmful stimuli

Light enters the eye through the cornea, passes through the pupil (regulated by the iris), is focused by the lens, and strikes the retina — a thin layer of neural tissue at the back of the eye containing the photoreceptors

Hubel and Wiesel's Nobel Prize-winning research identified feature detectors in the primary visual cortex (V1): simple cells respond to lines and edges at specific orientations and locations; complex cells respond to moving lines at specific orientations regardless of exact position; and hypercomplex cells respond to lines of specific length or endpoints. This hierarchical processing demonstrates how the visual cortex builds complex representations from simple features

Sound waves are converted to neural signals through the mechanical structures of the ear (outer ear, tympanic membrane, ossicles) and the cochlea, where hair cells on the basilar membrane transduce mechanical vibration into electrical signals

Modern understanding: place theory and frequency/volley theory are complementary. Low frequencies are coded primarily by firing rate (frequency theory), high frequencies are coded by the location of maximal basilar membrane displacement (place theory), and intermediate frequencies use both mechanisms
The Gestalt principles describe how the visual system organizes individual elements into coherent wholes ("the whole is different from the sum of its parts"):

Binocular cues (requiring both eyes): retinal disparity (each eye receives a slightly different image; greater disparity = closer object) and convergence (the inward turning of the eyes for near objects). Monocular cues (available from one eye): relative size, interposition (overlap), linear perspective, texture gradient, aerial perspective (haziness), and motion parallax

Attention determines which of the vast amount of incoming sensory information reaches conscious awareness and receives further processing. A central debate in cognitive psychology concerns where in the processing stream selection occurs — early (before meaning is extracted) or late (after full semantic analysis). The major models of attention are frequently tested on the EPPP

Deutsch and Deutsch (1963), later refined by Norman (1968), proposed a late selection model in which all incoming information is fully processed for meaning (semantically analyzed), and selection occurs only at the response/awareness stage. According to this model, the bottleneck is not in perception but in the decision about what to act on or remember. This explains how people can be influenced by the meaning of unattended messages without being consciously aware of them

Sleep Spindles & K-Complexes: Sleep spindles are brief bursts of 12-14 Hz activity generated by the thalamus during NREM Stage 2. They are believed to play a role in memory consolidation and protecting sleep from external disturbances. K-complexes are large, sharp waveforms that also appear in Stage 2; they are thought to represent cortical responses to external stimuli and may function in sleep maintenance

NREM Parasomnias (Disorders of Arousal): Sleepwalking (somnambulism) and night terrors (sleep terrors) occur during NREM Stage 3 (slow-wave sleep), typically in the first third of the night. During night terrors, the individual may sit up screaming with autonomic arousal (tachycardia, sweating) but has no memory of the event. These parasomnias are most common in children and usually resolve with maturation. They should be distinguished from nightmares, which occur during REM sleep

REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD): REM sleep behavior disorder involves loss of the normal muscle atonia during REM sleep, allowing individuals to physically act out their dreams. RBD is a strong prodromal marker for synucleinopathies — a significant percentage of patients with RBD eventually develop Parkinson's disease or Lewy body dementia. This association is high-yield for the EPPP

passages.section: Sleep Across the Lifespan & Deprivation Effects
passages.passage: Sleep Deprivation Effects: Chronic sleep deprivation impairs attention, working memory, decision-making, emotional regulation, and immune function. Sleep-deprived individuals show increased activity in the amygdala and decreased prefrontal cortex regulation, leading to heightened emotional reactivity. Severe prolonged sleep deprivation can produce perceptual disturbances, paranoia, and psychotic-like symptoms. Growth hormone, which is primarily secreted during slow-wave sleep, is also affected — relevant for pediatric growth and recovery from illness

Clinical Application: Exogenous melatonin is used therapeutically for circadian rhythm disorders, jet lag, and as an adjunct for insomnia. The timing of administration is critical: melatonin given in the evening advances the circadian phase (useful for delayed sleep-wake phase disorder), while melatonin given in the morning delays the phase. Blue-light-blocking glasses in the evening can also advance sleep onset by preventing melatonin suppression

Sleep is organized into a cyclic architecture of NREM (non-rapid eye movement) and REM (rapid eye movement) stages, each with characteristic electroencephalographic (EEG) signatures. A complete sleep cycle lasts approximately 90 minutes, with 4-6 cycles occurring per night

As the night progresses, NREM Stage 3 (slow-wave sleep) decreases while REM periods become progressively longer. Most slow-wave sleep occurs in the first third of the night, while most REM sleep occurs in the last third. This distribution has important implications: disruptions to early-night sleep primarily affect slow-wave sleep (and declarative memory consolidation), while disruptions to late-night sleep primarily affect REM sleep (and procedural/emotional memory processing)

Circadian rhythms are endogenous biological cycles with a period of approximately 24 hours that regulate sleep-wake cycles, hormone secretion, body temperature, and other physiological processes. The master circadian clock is the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) , located in the anterior hypothalamus directly above the optic chiasm

The SCN receives light information directly from the retina via the retinohypothalamic tract (using specialized melanopsin-containing retinal ganglion cells), allowing it to synchronize the internal clock with the external light-dark cycle. The SCN projects to the pineal gland , which secretes melatonin during darkness. Melatonin promotes sleep onset and is suppressed by light exposure, particularly blue-wavelength light

Insomnia disorder involves difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep, or early morning awakening, at least three nights per week for at least three months, causing significant distress or functional impairment. Cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) is the first-line treatment and includes stimulus control, sleep restriction, sleep hygiene education, cognitive restructuring, and relaxation training

Narcolepsy is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness and may include cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by strong emotions), hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations, and sleep paralysis. Type 1 narcolepsy involves deficiency of hypocretin (orexin) , a neuropeptide produced by the lateral hypothalamus that promotes wakefulness. The loss of hypocretin-producing neurons is believed to result from autoimmune destruction

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) involves repeated episodes of upper airway collapse during sleep, producing apneas (cessation of breathing for 10+ seconds) or hypopneas (partial airway obstruction). OSA disrupts sleep architecture, reduces oxygen saturation, and is associated with cardiovascular disease, cognitive impairment, and excessive daytime sleepiness. Treatment includes CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure)

Subcortical: Refers to structures situated below the cerebral cortex, including the thalamus, hypothalamus, basal ganglia, limbic system structures, brainstem, and cerebellum. These regions are phylogenetically older and more critical for survival-related functions than cortical structures

Cerebellar Damage: Produces ataxia (loss of coordination), dysarthria (slurred speech), intention tremor (tremor that worsens as the hand approaches a target, in contrast to Parkinson's resting tremor), nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), and gait instability. Cerebellar damage does NOT cause paralysis

Clinical Significance: Olfaction (smell) is the only sensory modality that does not relay through the thalamus. Olfactory information travels directly from the olfactory bulb to the piriform cortex and amygdala. This is a frequently tested fact on the EPPP

passages.section: Clinical Significance of Basal Ganglia Dysfunction
passages.passage: Clinical Significance: The direct pathway through the basal ganglia facilitates movement (excitatory net effect), while the indirect pathway inhibits movement (inhibitory net effect). Parkinson's disease (too little dopamine) results in difficulty initiating movement. Huntington's disease (loss of inhibitory neurons) results in excessive, uncontrolled movement

Clinical Significance: The RAS is clinically important for understanding disorders of consciousness. Coma results from bilateral cortical damage or damage to the RAS. Damage to specific brainstem regions can produce "locked-in syndrome," where patients are conscious but unable to move or communicate except through eye movements

EPPP Application: Lesion studies are frequently tested. Remember: lateral hypothalamus lesions produce "lateral leanness" (aphagia/weight loss), while ventromedial hypothalamus lesions produce "ventromedial voluminosity" (hyperphagia/obesity). These mnemonics appear on many EPPP study resources

Subcortical structures are brain regions located beneath the cerebral cortex that perform vital functions including relaying sensory information, regulating homeostasis, coordinating movement, and mediating emotion and memory. For the EPPP, it is essential to know the key subcortical structures, their locations, their functions, and the clinical consequences of their damage

The thalamus is a large, egg-shaped structure sitting atop the brainstem at the center of the brain. It serves as the brain's primary sensory relay station, routing incoming sensory information to the appropriate cortical areas

The hypothalamus is a small structure (approximately the size of an almond) located below the thalamus. Despite its small size, it is critical for maintaining homeostasis and regulating the endocrine system through its connection with the pituitary gland

The limbic system is a collection of interconnected structures surrounding the thalamus that mediate emotion, motivation, learning, and memory. While the exact boundaries of the limbic system are debated, the following structures are consistently included:

A seahorse-shaped structure in the medial temporal lobe that is essential for the consolidation of new declarative (explicit) memories -- the transfer of information from short-term to long-term storage
An almond-shaped structure anterior to the hippocampus, the amygdala is the brain's "fear center" and is critical for emotional processing, particularly fear conditioning and threat detection
The basal ganglia are a group of subcortical nuclei involved in the initiation, execution, and modulation of voluntary movement, as well as procedural learning and habit formation
The brainstem connects the cerebral hemispheres to the spinal cord and controls vital autonomic functions. It consists of three major divisions:

The cerebellum ("little brain") is located posterior to the brainstem and contains more neurons than the rest of the brain combined. Although comprising only 10% of brain volume, it contains approximately 50% of the brain's neurons

The reticular activating system is a network of neurons extending through the brainstem core from the medulla to the midbrain. It plays a critical role in regulating consciousness, arousal, and the sleep-wake cycle
Language production and comprehension (in ~95% of right-handers and ~70% of left-handers)
Lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN): Relays visual information from the optic tract to the primary visual cortex (V1)
Medial geniculate nucleus (MGN): Relays auditory information from the inferior colliculus to the primary auditory cortex
Ventral posterolateral (VPL) nucleus: Relays somatosensory information from the body to the primary somatosensory cortex
Ventral posteromedial (VPM) nucleus: Relays somatosensory information from the face
Dorsomedial nucleus: Connects to the prefrontal cortex; involved in memory and emotion. Damage is implicated in Korsakoff's syndrome.

Fighting (aggression): The ventromedial hypothalamus is involved in aggressive behavior. Electrical stimulation of the medial hypothalamus produces affective (emotional) attack behavior, while stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus produces predatory stalking attack behavior.
Fleeing (fear responses): Coordinates autonomic fear responses through connections with the amygdala and brainstem

Feeding: The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is the "hunger center" — stimulation induces eating, and lesions cause aphagia (refusal to eat). The ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH) is the "satiety center" — stimulation inhibits eating, and lesions cause hyperphagia (overeating) and obesity.
Mating (sexual behavior): Regulates sexual behavior and reproductive functions; the sexually dimorphic nucleus differs in size between males and females
Thermoregulation: Maintains body temperature through sweating, shivering, and vasoconstriction/vasodilation

Circadian rhythms: The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) serves as the master biological clock, entrained by light input from the retina. It controls the sleep-wake cycle by triggering changes in melatonin release by the pineal gland.
Endocrine control: Regulates the pituitary gland ("master gland") through releasing and inhibiting hormones. Controls the HPA axis (hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis) for stress responses.
Thirst and water balance: Osmoreceptors detect blood osmolarity changes and trigger thirst and ADH release

Oxytocin production: The hypothalamus produces oxytocin, which stimulates milk ejection during breastfeeding and plays roles in social bonding. Research shows that increasing oxytocin levels in healthy adults can cause them to become overly sensitive to emotional facial expressions of others.
Bilateral hippocampal damage produces severe anterograde amnesia for declarative information (the case of patient H.M.)
Contains place cells (O'Keefe, Nobel Prize 2014) that fire when an animal occupies a specific location, forming cognitive maps for spatial navigation
One of only two brain regions where adult neurogenesis has been confirmed (the other is the olfactory bulb/subventricular zone)
Particularly vulnerable to damage from chronic stress — stress-induced increases in cortisol are neurotoxic to hippocampal neurons and have been linked to impairments in declarative memory retrieval
Neuroimaging studies have linked PTSD to a reduced hippocampal volume, decreased activity in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex, and increased activity in the amygdala
Receives rapid, coarse sensory input via a direct pathway from the thalamus (LeDoux's "low road"), enabling fast fear responses before cortical processing is complete
Also receives slower, detailed input from the cortex ("high road") for more nuanced evaluation
The consolidation of emotional memories is mediated primarily by the amygdala — amygdala activation enhances hippocampal encoding of emotionally arousing events
People with bilateral damage to the amygdala often have difficulty recognizing negative emotions in facial expressions, especially fear
Electrical stimulation of certain areas of the amygdala elicits conditioned fear responses: freezing, increased heart rate and blood pressure, and release of stress hormones

Anterior cingulate cortex (ACC): Involved in error detection, conflict monitoring, pain perception, and emotional regulation. A meta-analysis of neuroimaging studies found that psychotherapy for major depressive disorder increased activity in the cingulate cortex.
Posterior cingulate cortex (PCC): Part of the default mode network; involved in self-referential processing and autobiographical memory. One of the first regions affected in Alzheimer's disease.

Mammillary bodies: Part of the Papez circuit (which plays a fundamental role in emotions and memory). Relay information from the hippocampus to the thalamus. Degeneration occurs in Korsakoff's syndrome and contributes to anterograde amnesia and confabulation.
Fornix: Major white matter tract connecting the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies and septal nuclei
Caudate nucleus: Involved in cognitive control of movement, goal-directed behavior, and procedural memory

Putamen: Primary motor component; involved in the initiation and execution of movement. Together with the caudate, forms the striatum (so named for its striped appearance). Areas of the cerebral cortex involved in planning and execution of movement send excitatory signals to the striatum.
Globus pallidus: Output nucleus of the basal ganglia; sends inhibitory signals to the thalamus to regulate motor activity
Subthalamic nucleus: Regulates the globus pallidus; lesions can cause hemiballismus (violent flinging movements of contralateral limbs). Deep brain stimulation here can reduce Parkinsonian symptoms.

Substantia nigra: Located in the midbrain; its pars compacta produces dopamine sent to the striatum via the nigrostriatal pathway. Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons here is the primary pathology of Parkinson's disease.
Superior colliculi: Visual reflexes and orienting responses (e.g., turning the head toward a visual stimulus)
Inferior colliculi: Auditory reflexes and relay of auditory information to the thalamus
Substantia nigra: Dopamine production for motor control (part of basal ganglia circuitry); degeneration causes Parkinson's disease
Ventral tegmental area (VTA): Dopamine production for the mesolimbic reward pathway (projects to nucleus accumbens and prefrontal cortex); critical for reward, motivation, and addiction
Contains nuclei for cranial nerves V (trigeminal), VI (abducens), VII (facial), and VIII (vestibulocochlear)

Contains the locus coeruleus, the brain's primary source of norepinephrine, involved in arousal, attention, and the stress response. The locus coeruleus has also been identified as "ground zero" for Alzheimer's disease.
Controls respiration — an overdose of morphine, heroin, or other opioids can cause respiratory failure because of the drug's effects on opioid receptors in the medulla
Contains the raphe nuclei, the brain's primary source of serotonin, involved in mood regulation and sleep
Site of the pyramidal decussation, where motor fibers cross from one side to the other (explaining contralateral motor control)
Motor coordination: Fine-tunes motor output for smooth, coordinated, accurate movements

Motor learning: Essential for acquiring skilled movements and classical conditioning of motor responses (e.g., eyeblink conditioning). Implicit memories (procedural memory and conditioned responses) are stored in the cerebellum and basal ganglia.
Timing: Internal clock for the precise timing of movements and cognitive operations
Cognitive functions: Increasingly recognized role in language, attention, and executive function
Filters incoming sensory information, determining what reaches conscious awareness
Maintains cortical alertness through diffuse projections to the thalamus and cortex
Electrical stimulation of the ascending RAS will wake up a sleeping person and cause an awake person to become more alert

Amygdala: Central to fear conditioning, threat detection, and the emotional modulation of memory. Bilateral amygdala damage (as in Kluver-Bucy syndrome) produces placidity, hyperorality, visual agnosia, and altered emotional responses. The amygdala is hyperactive in PTSD and anxiety disorders.
Hippocampus: Critical for declarative memory formation; also involved in contextual fear conditioning and stress regulation. Chronic stress and elevated cortisol cause hippocampal atrophy.

Hypothalamus: Regulates the autonomic nervous system, endocrine system (via the pituitary), and homeostatic drives (hunger, thirst, temperature, sexual behavior). Contains the suprachiasmatic nucleus (circadian rhythms) and releases corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) to activate the HPA axis.
Cingulate cortex: The anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) is involved in error detection, conflict monitoring, and the affective component of pain. It connects emotional processing to executive control.
James-Lange: body response comes first, then emotion ("I'm afraid because my heart is racing")
Cannon-Bard: body response and emotion occur simultaneously; mediated by thalamus
Schachter-Singer (two-factor): emotion = physiological arousal + cognitive label; demonstrates misattribution of arousal
Lazarus: cognitive appraisal must come before emotion; appraisal determines which emotion is experienced
Facial feedback hypothesis: facial expressions can influence (not just reflect) emotional experience
Yerkes-Dodson law: inverted-U relationship between arousal and performance; optimal arousal is LOWER for complex tasks, HIGHER for simple tasks
Sympathetic NS: fight-or-flight (norepinephrine); Parasympathetic NS: rest-and-digest (acetylcholine)

Ekman's 6 basic emotions: happiness, sadness, anger, fear, disgust, surprise — universally recognized across cultures; later added contempt

Allostasis: The process by which the body achieves stability through physiological change (as opposed to homeostasis, which maintains a fixed set point)

Stress and immunity: Acute stress can temporarily enhance immune function (mobilizing natural killer cells), while chronic stress suppresses immune function through sustained cortisol elevation

Anabolic steroid abuse can cause mood instability, aggression ("roid rage"), and psychotic symptoms.

Estrogen: Has neuroprotective effects, modulates serotonin receptors, and influences mood regulation. Estrogen decline after menopause is associated with increased risk for Alzheimer's disease.

Oxytocin: Released during childbirth, breastfeeding, and social bonding. Promotes trust, pair bonding, and social recognition. Sometimes called the "bonding hormone," though its effects are context-dependent and more nuanced than popular accounts suggest.

Method of loci: Associating items to be remembered with specific locations along a familiar mental route. This ancient technique creates vivid spatial-visual associations and is highly effective for ordered recall.

Keyword method: Used for vocabulary learning; the learner creates a concrete image linking the sound of the unfamiliar word to the meaning through an intermediary keyword. Particularly effective for foreign language acquisition.
Pegword method: Items are associated with a pre-memorized sequence of rhyming cue words (e.g., "one is a bun, two is a shoe"). Useful for learning numbered lists.
Levels of processing (Craik & Lockhart): deep/semantic processing produces better memory than shallow/structural processing
Elaborative rehearsal (connecting to meaning) produces better retention than maintenance rehearsal (simple repetition)
Encoding specificity principle (Tulving & Thomson): retrieval is best when encoding and retrieval conditions match
Context-dependent memory: external environment match enhances recall; State-dependent memory: internal state match enhances recall
Generation effect: actively producing information is better than passively reading it
Testing effect (retrieval practice): self-testing is more effective than restudying for long-term retention
Spacing effect: distributed practice produces superior retention compared to massed practice
Dual coding theory (Paivio): encoding in both verbal and visual systems creates two retrieval routes

Transfer-appropriate processing: memory depends on the match between encoding type and retrieval demands, not just "depth"
Encoding failure: forgetting because information was never adequately encoded in the first place

Iconic memory (visual): Demonstrated by Sperling's (1960) partial-report paradigm, iconic memory holds a nearly complete visual image for approximately 250-500 milliseconds. Sperling showed that participants could report any row of a briefly flashed letter array when cued immediately, but this advantage disappeared after about half a second, indicating rapid decay of the iconic trace.

Echoic memory (auditory): Retains auditory information for approximately 3-4 seconds. This longer duration explains why you can "replay" something someone just said, even if you were not initially attending to it.
Phonological similarity effect: Lists of similar-sounding items (B, D, G, T, P) are harder to recall than dissimilar items, because they produce confusable representations in the phonological store.
Word-length effect: Lists of long words are harder to recall than short words, because longer words take more time to rehearse in the articulatory loop.
Atkinson-Shiffrin model: sensory memory (brief, high capacity) → short-term memory (limited capacity, ~30 sec) → long-term memory (unlimited capacity, permanent)
Iconic memory (Sperling): visual sensory memory lasting ~250-500 ms; Echoic memory: auditory sensory memory lasting ~3-4 seconds
Miller's magical number: STM capacity is 7 plus or minus 2 items; chunking increases effective capacity
Baddeley's working memory: phonological loop (verbal), visuospatial sketchpad (visual-spatial), central executive (attention control), episodic buffer (integration)
Selective interference: tasks sharing the same working memory subsystem interfere more than tasks using different subsystems
Declarative memory (explicit, hippocampus-dependent) vs. procedural memory (implicit, basal ganglia/cerebellum-dependent)
Episodic memory (personal events in time/place) vs. semantic memory (general knowledge, facts) — both are declarative
Priming: a form of implicit memory; amnesic patients show intact priming despite impaired explicit memory
Amnesic patients demonstrate the explicit/implicit dissociation: impaired conscious recollection but intact procedural learning and priming
The central executive is the most clinically relevant working memory component; deficits are associated with prefrontal cortex damage and ADHD
Sensory memory holds a brief, relatively complete record of sensory experience. Two forms are most studied:

Structural (shallow) processing: Encoding based on physical features of the stimulus, such as the appearance of printed words (e.g., "Is this word in uppercase letters?"). This produces the weakest memory traces.
Phonemic (intermediate) processing: Encoding based on how a stimulus sounds (e.g., "Does this word rhyme with 'train'?"). This produces moderate memory strength.

Semantic (deep) processing: Encoding based on the meaning of information (e.g., "Does this word fit in the sentence: 'The _____ crossed the road'?"). This produces the strongest and most durable memories.
Explicit (declarative) memory: Conscious recollection of facts and events Episodic memory: Personal experiences and events (Tulving, 1972) Semantic memory: General knowledge and facts about the world

Implicit (nondeclarative) memory: Memory without conscious awareness Procedural memory: Motor skills and habits (e.g., riding a bicycle) Priming: Facilitated processing of a stimulus due to prior exposure Classical conditioning: Learned associations between stimuli
Central executive: An attentional control system that directs focus, coordinates the subsystems, and manages cognitive resources. It has limited capacity and is modality-free.

Phonological loop: Maintains and rehearses verbal and acoustic information. Consists of a phonological store (the "inner ear") and an articulatory rehearsal process (the "inner voice"). Explains the word-length effect (shorter words are recalled better because they can be rehearsed faster).
Visuospatial sketchpad: Maintains and manipulates visual and spatial information (the "inner eye"). Used in navigation, mental imagery, and spatial reasoning.

Episodic buffer (added 2000): Integrates information from the phonological loop, visuospatial sketchpad, and long-term memory into unified, coherent episodes. Serves as a limited-capacity temporary store.

Recall: Retrieving information without explicit cues. More demanding than recognition. Free recall (produce items in any order), serial recall (produce items in order), and cued recall (use a hint) are subtypes.
Recognition: Identifying previously encountered information from a set of options. Generally easier than recall because the target item serves as its own retrieval cue.

Relearning (savings method): Ebbinghaus's measure showing that previously learned material is relearned faster, even when conscious recall fails. The difference in learning trials is the "savings score."
Proactive interference: Previously learned information interferes with the ability to learn or recall new information. ("Old" disrupts "new.")
Retroactive interference: Newly learned information interferes with the ability to recall previously learned information. ("New" disrupts "old.")
Transient global amnesia: Temporary anterograde (and sometimes retrograde) amnesia lasting hours, often in older adults. Cause is unclear but may involve transient ischemia.

Korsakoff's syndrome: Amnesia resulting from thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, typically due to chronic alcoholism. Characterized by severe anterograde amnesia, confabulation, and damage to the mammillary bodies and dorsomedial thalamus.
Dissociative (psychogenic) amnesia: Memory loss for personal information following psychological trauma, without identifiable neurological damage.
Hippocampus: Critical for consolidation of new declarative memories from short-term to long-term storage. Damage causes anterograde amnesia for declarative information.
Amygdala: Modulates emotional memory consolidation. Emotionally arousing events are remembered better partly through amygdala-hippocampal interactions.
Prefrontal cortex: Involved in working memory, strategic encoding, and retrieval monitoring.
Cerebellum and basal ganglia: Essential for procedural memory and motor skill learning.
Perirhinal and entorhinal cortices: Contribute to recognition memory and serve as relays between neocortex and hippocampus.
Source monitoring errors: Misattributing the source of a memory (e.g., confusing something imagined with something experienced).
False memories: Deese-Roediger-McDermott (DRM) paradigm demonstrates that presenting lists of semantically related words reliably produces false memories of non-presented critical lure words.

Flashbulb memories: Vivid, confident memories for emotionally significant events. Despite high subjective confidence, accuracy of these memories declines over time similarly to ordinary memories (Talarico & Rubin, 2003).

Early stage: Episodic memory impairment (forgetting recent events, repeating questions), word-finding difficulty, misplacing items, mild executive dysfunction. Procedural memory and remote memories are relatively preserved. Patients may show anosognosia (lack of awareness of deficits).

Middle stage: More pronounced memory loss (may not recognize family members), visuospatial disorientation (getting lost), language deterioration (fluent but empty speech), apraxia (difficulty with learned motor sequences), behavioral symptoms (agitation, wandering, sundowning, delusions of theft, paranoia).
Late stage: Severe cognitive decline across all domains, loss of ability to speak, walk, and swallow. Incontinence, bedbound state. Average duration from diagnosis to death is 8-10 years.
Multi-infarct dementia: Multiple large-vessel strokes producing cumulative cognitive damage. The cognitive profile depends on stroke locations.

Small vessel disease (subcortical vascular dementia): Chronic, progressive white matter ischemia (leukoaraiosis) producing executive dysfunction, psychomotor slowing, and gait abnormality. More gradual than multi-infarct type.
Strategic infarct dementia: A single stroke in a critical area (e.g., thalamus, angular gyrus, hippocampus) producing disproportionate cognitive impairment.
Major vs. mild NCD: The critical distinction is functional independence -- major NCD interferes with daily functioning; mild NCD does not
Alzheimer's disease: Most common dementia; amyloid plaques + neurofibrillary tangles; begins in hippocampus/entorhinal cortex; the "4 A's" (amnesia, aphasia, agnosia, apraxia)
APOE-e4: Strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset AD; one copy = 3-4x risk, two copies = 12-15x risk; risk factor, not deterministic

Cortical vs. subcortical dementia: Cortical (AD) = amnesia/aphasia/agnosia/apraxia, encoding deficit; Subcortical (Parkinson's, Huntington's) = slowed processing, executive dysfunction, retrieval deficit (improves with cues)
Vascular NCD: Stepwise decline, temporal relationship to strokes, early executive dysfunction, focal neurological signs, cerebrovascular risk factors
Lewy body dementia: Fluctuating cognition, vivid visual hallucinations, REM sleep behavior disorder, parkinsonism, SEVERE neuroleptic sensitivity (life-threatening)

Frontotemporal NCD: Earlier onset (45-65), personality/behavior changes before memory loss; behavioral variant = disinhibition/apathy; semantic PPA = loss of word meaning; nonfluent PPA = effortful speech

Delirium vs. dementia: Delirium = acute onset, fluctuating course, impaired attention/consciousness, usually reversible; Dementia = insidious onset, progressive, clear consciousness, usually irreversible
CJD: Rapid progressive dementia (weeks-months) + myoclonus + periodic sharp-wave EEG; prion disease; fatal within ~1 year
NPH: "Wet, wobbly, wacky" (incontinence, gait disturbance, dementia); reversible with VP shunt; ventriculomegaly on imaging
Wernicke-Korsakoff: Wernicke (acute: confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia -- emergency IV thiamine); Korsakoff (chronic: anterograde amnesia, confabulation, mammillary bodies)
HIV-associated NCD: Subcortical profile (psychomotor slowing, executive dysfunction, retrieval deficits); dramatically decreased with ART
The six cognitive domains assessed in the DSM-5 NCD framework are:

Huntington's disease: autosomal dominant; CAG trinucleotide repeat on chromosome 4; caudate nucleus atrophy; chorea; 100% penetrance
Parkinson's = hypokinetic (too little movement); Huntington's = hyperkinetic (too much movement/chorea)
Multiple sclerosis: autoimmune CNS demyelination; relapsing-remitting is most common form; Uhthoff's phenomenon (heat worsens symptoms)
ALS: upper and lower motor neuron degeneration; progressive weakness; cognition typically preserved; fatal within 3-5 years
Wilson's disease: copper accumulation; Kayser-Fleischer rings; basal ganglia involvement; treatable
Myasthenia gravis: ACh receptor antibodies at neuromuscular junction; weakness worsens with activity; ptosis and diplopia
Cerebellar signs: ataxia, dysmetria, intention tremor, dysarthria; signs are IPSILATERAL to the lesion
Intention tremor (cerebellar) worsens on reaching; resting tremor (Parkinson's) diminishes with movement

Focal aware seizures (formerly "simple partial"): Consciousness is preserved. Symptoms depend on the brain region involved -- motor (jerking), sensory (tingling, visual disturbances), autonomic (nausea, sweating), or psychic (deja vu, fear, hallucinations). An aura is a focal aware seizure that precedes a larger seizure.

Focal impaired awareness seizures (formerly "complex partial"): Consciousness is altered. Most commonly originate in the temporal lobe. Typically feature automatisms (repetitive purposeless movements such as lip smacking, picking at clothes, or wandering). Patients are amnestic for the event.
Focal to bilateral tonic-clonic: Begins focally and then spreads to both hemispheres (secondarily generalized).

Tonic-clonic (formerly "grand mal"): A tonic phase (muscle rigidity, loss of consciousness, possible cry) followed by a clonic phase (rhythmic jerking of all extremities). Postictal confusion and sleepiness follow.

Absence (formerly "petit mal"): Brief (5-30 second) episodes of staring and unresponsiveness, often with subtle motor signs (eye blinking, lip movements). EEG shows characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave pattern. Most common in children and may be mistaken for daydreaming or ADHD.
Interictal personality changes (Geschwind syndrome: hypergraphia, hyperreligiosity, altered sexuality, viscosity)
Psychiatric comorbidities: depression (30-50%), anxiety, and psychosis-like symptoms
Tremor: Resting tremor (4-6 Hz), often described as "pill-rolling." Decreases during intentional movement (in contrast to cerebellar intention tremor).
Rigidity: Increased muscle tone throughout range of motion. "Cogwheel rigidity" (ratchet-like resistance) is characteristic.

Akinesia/Bradykinesia: Slowness of movement (bradykinesia) or difficulty initiating movement (akinesia). Includes reduced facial expressiveness (masked facies), small handwriting (micrographia), and shuffling gait.
Postural instability: Impaired balance and righting reflexes, leading to falls. Typically a later symptom.
Cognitive impairment: Executive dysfunction (frontal-subcortical deficits); approximately 75-80% develop dementia over the disease course
Autonomic dysfunction: Constipation, orthostatic hypotension, urinary dysfunction
Psychosis: Visual hallucinations, particularly with advancing disease and dopaminergic medications

L-dopa (levodopa): The dopamine precursor that crosses the blood-brain barrier and is converted to dopamine in the brain. Combined with carbidopa (which prevents peripheral conversion). Most effective treatment but associated with motor fluctuations ("wearing off," "on-off" phenomenon) and dyskinesias with long-term use.
Dopamine agonists: Pramipexole, ropinirole (directly stimulate dopamine receptors). Side effects may include impulse control disorders (gambling, hypersexuality, compulsive shopping).
Deep brain stimulation (DBS): Electrodes implanted in the subthalamic nucleus or globus pallidus for medication-refractory symptoms
Chorea: Involuntary, irregular, writhing, dance-like movements (the opposite of Parkinson's hypokinesia)
Cognitive decline: Subcortical dementia pattern with executive dysfunction, slowed processing speed, and memory retrieval deficits (as opposed to the encoding deficits in Alzheimer's)
Psychiatric symptoms: Depression, irritability, apathy, and psychosis; personality and mood changes often precede motor symptoms by years
Demographics: Typically diagnosed between ages 20-40; more common in women (2-3:1 ratio) and in populations farther from the equator

Symptoms are variable and depend on the location of plaques: visual disturbances (optic neuritis), motor weakness, sensory changes (numbness, tingling), fatigue, bladder dysfunction, and cognitive impairment (slowed processing, attention and memory deficits)
Relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS): The most common form (85%); discrete attacks followed by partial or full recovery
Primary progressive MS: Steady worsening from onset without distinct relapses (10-15%)
Secondary progressive MS: Initially relapsing-remitting, then transitions to progressive worsening

Middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke: Most common. Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss (face and arm greater than leg); aphasia if left hemisphere (Broca's, Wernicke's, or global); hemispatial neglect if right hemisphere.
Anterior cerebral artery (ACA) stroke: Contralateral leg weakness greater than arm; personality changes; abulia (loss of will/motivation); urinary incontinence.
Posterior cerebral artery (PCA) stroke: Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia (visual field loss); memory impairment if medial temporal structures are affected.
Contrecoup injury: Damage at the opposite side of the brain from the impact, caused by the brain bouncing against the skull
Diffuse axonal injury (DAI): Widespread shearing of axons due to rotational forces; the most common cause of severe TBI disability
Epidural hematoma: Bleeding between skull and dura mater, typically from middle meningeal artery rupture. "Lucid interval" followed by rapid deterioration.
Subdural hematoma: Bleeding between dura and arachnoid, from bridging vein rupture. Can be acute or chronic (common in elderly, alcoholics).

Soma (cell body): Contains the nucleus and organelles; integrates incoming signals from dendrites
Dendrites: Branching extensions that receive signals from other neurons; the primary input structures
Axon: A single long fiber that conducts action potentials away from the soma toward the terminal buttons
Myelin sheath: A fatty insulating layer produced by oligodendrocytes (CNS) or Schwann cells (PNS) that dramatically increases conduction speed
Nodes of Ranvier: Gaps in the myelin sheath where ion channels are concentrated, enabling saltatory conduction
Terminal buttons (axon terminals): End points of the axon that release neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft
Depolarization: Voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels open, allowing rapid Na+ influx. The membrane potential rises toward +30 to +40 mV.
Repolarization: Na+ channels inactivate and voltage-gated potassium (K+) channels open, allowing K+ efflux. The membrane potential returns toward resting level.
Hyperpolarization: K+ channels remain open briefly, causing the membrane to overshoot below resting potential (~-80 mV) before returning to -70 mV.
The action potential arrives at the terminal button and triggers calcium (Ca2+) influx through voltage-gated calcium channels
Ca2+ causes synaptic vesicles to fuse with the presynaptic membrane and release neurotransmitter into the synaptic cleft (exocytosis)
Neurotransmitter molecules bind to postsynaptic receptors, producing excitatory or inhibitory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs or IPSPs)
Neurotransmitter action is terminated by reuptake, enzymatic degradation, or diffusion away from the synapse
If MZ concordance is substantially higher than DZ concordance, genetic factors are implicated
If MZ concordance is similar to DZ concordance, shared environmental factors are more important
If MZ concordance is less than 100%, environmental factors play a role (since MZ twins are genetically identical)

MZ twins reared apart provide the strongest evidence for genetic influence, as any similarity cannot be attributed to shared rearing environment (e.g., the Minnesota Study of Twins Reared Apart; Bouchard et al., 1990)

Gene-environment interaction (GxE): The effect of a gene on a phenotype depends on the environment, and vice versa. The same genotype produces different outcomes in different environments. Classic example: Caspi et al. (2003) found that individuals with the short allele of the serotonin transporter gene (5-HTTLPR) were more likely to develop depression following stressful life events than those with the long allele — the genetic vulnerability was only expressed under environmental stress.

Gene-environment correlation (rGE): Genetic factors influence the probability of exposure to certain environments. Three types: Passive rGE: Children passively inherit both genes and environments from their parents (e.g., musically gifted parents both pass on music-related genes and provide a musical home environment) Evocative (reactive) rGE: A person's genetically influenced characteristics evoke particular responses from others (e.g., a genetically temperamental child elicits harsh parenting) Active rGE (niche-picking): Individuals actively select environments that match their genetic predispositions (e.g., an extraverted adolescent seeks out social activities). Active rGE becomes increasingly important with age as individuals gain more autonomy over their environment.
Passive rGE: Children passively inherit both genes and environments from their parents (e.g., musically gifted parents both pass on music-related genes and provide a musical home environment)
Evocative (reactive) rGE: A person's genetically influenced characteristics evoke particular responses from others (e.g., a genetically temperamental child elicits harsh parenting)

Active rGE (niche-picking): Individuals actively select environments that match their genetic predispositions (e.g., an extraverted adolescent seeks out social activities). Active rGE becomes increasingly important with age as individuals gain more autonomy over their environment.
Neuron structure: dendrites (receive signals) → soma (integrates) → axon (conducts) → terminal buttons (release neurotransmitter)
Resting potential = -70 mV; threshold = ~-55 mV; action potential peaks at ~+30 to +40 mV
All-or-none law: action potentials fire at full amplitude or not at all; intensity coded by firing rate
Saltatory conduction: action potentials jump between nodes of Ranvier on myelinated axons; much faster than continuous conduction
Reuptake: primary mechanism for terminating neurotransmitter action at many synapses; SSRIs block serotonin reuptake
Agonist = mimics/enhances neurotransmitter; Antagonist = blocks/reduces neurotransmitter action
GABA = main inhibitory NT; Glutamate = main excitatory NT; know their clinical associations
Dopamine pathways: mesolimbic (reward/positive symptoms), mesocortical (executive function/negative symptoms), nigrostriatal (motor/Parkinson's), tuberoinfundibular (prolactin)
Acetylcholine deficit in Alzheimer's; treated with cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine)
Excitotoxicity: excessive glutamate kills neurons; occurs in stroke, TBI, and neurodegenerative disease
Heritability (h²): proportion of trait variance attributable to genetic differences IN A POPULATION — NOT how much of an individual's trait is "genetic"; high heritability does not mean immutable
Twin studies: MZ concordance >> DZ concordance = genetic contribution; MZ concordance < 100% = environmental contribution; MZ twins reared apart = strongest design
Shared vs. nonshared environment: nonshared environment explains more variance in personality and psychopathology than shared (family-wide) environment

GxE interaction: gene effect depends on environment (5-HTTLPR x stress = depression); rGE correlation: passive (inherit genes + environment), evocative (genes elicit responses), active/niche-picking (select matching environments)

Key heritability estimates: schizophrenia ~.80, bipolar ~.85, MDD ~.37, IQ ~.50-.80 (increases with age), personality ~.40-.60; Epigenetics: environment alters gene expression without changing DNA sequence (methylation, histone modification)
Two distinct processes describe how genes and environments work together:
Hippocampus: essential for consolidation of new declarative (explicit) memories; not the permanent storage site
H.M.: bilateral hippocampal removal caused severe anterograde amnesia with intact procedural learning, priming, and working memory — proved explicit and implicit memory are separate systems
Anterograde amnesia = cannot form new memories; Retrograde amnesia = cannot retrieve old memories; temporal gradient = recent memories lost more than remote
Korsakoff's syndrome: thiamine deficiency (chronic alcohol use) damages mammillary bodies and thalamus; produces amnesia + confabulation
Confabulation: fabricating memories to fill gaps, without intent to deceive — hallmark of Korsakoff's
Long-term potentiation (LTP): persistent synaptic strengthening; the primary cellular mechanism of learning; involves NMDA receptors and calcium signaling
Hebb's rule: "cells that fire together wire together" — co-activation strengthens synaptic connections
Amygdala: modulates emotional memory enhancement (does not store the memory itself)
Cerebellum: procedural memory and conditioned motor responses (eyeblink conditioning)
Reconsolidation: retrieved memories become temporarily labile and can be modified — potential mechanism for updating traumatic memories in therapy
Recall (generate from memory) is harder than recognition (identify from alternatives); both are easier than relearning (savings method)
Serial position effect: primacy (LTM, rehearsal) + recency (STM, still active); distractor task eliminates recency but not primacy
Ebbinghaus forgetting curve: forgetting is most rapid immediately after learning, then decelerates
Proactive interference: old material disrupts learning of new (forward in time); Retroactive interference: new material disrupts recall of old (backward in time)
Cue-dependent forgetting: information is stored but inaccessible without proper cues; TOT phenomenon is a classic example
Misinformation effect (Loftus): post-event information alters memory for the original event; leading questions can implant false details
DRM paradigm: demonstrates spontaneous false memory for semantically related non-presented words
Source monitoring errors: correctly remembering information but misattributing its source
Recovered memory debate: both genuine recovered memories and false memories can exist; suggestive techniques create risk of false memories
Flashbulb memories: vivid and confidently held, but NOT necessarily more accurate than ordinary memories
High confidence does NOT equal high accuracy — this is a critical EPPP principle for eyewitness testimony and recovered memories

Rods (~120 million): Sensitive to low light levels (scotopic vision); located primarily in the periphery; provide black-and-white vision; no color sensitivity; high convergence onto ganglion cells (many rods feed one ganglion cell), producing high sensitivity but low acuity

Cones (~6 million): Function in bright light (photopic vision); concentrated in the fovea (center of the retina); provide color vision and high visual acuity; low convergence (one-to-one mapping in fovea), producing low sensitivity but high acuity
Proximity: Elements that are close together are perceived as belonging to the same group
Similarity: Elements that share features (color, shape, size) are grouped together
Continuity (good continuation): Elements arranged along a line or curve are perceived as related
Figure-ground: The visual field is automatically organized into a figure (the object of focus) and a ground (the background)

Inattentional blindness (Mack & Rock, 1998; Simons & Chabris, 1999): The failure to perceive a clearly visible stimulus when attention is directed elsewhere. In the famous "invisible gorilla" experiment, approximately 50% of observers failed to notice a person in a gorilla suit walking through a basketball game when they were counting passes. This demonstrates that attention, not just visual acuity, is necessary for conscious perception.

Change blindness (Rensink, O'Regan, & Clark, 1997): The failure to detect large changes in a visual scene when the change coincides with a brief visual disruption (e.g., a flicker, a saccade, or a cut in a film). Change blindness reveals that we do not maintain a detailed, moment-to-moment representation of the entire visual scene — our sense of a complete visual world is, in part, an illusion constructed by the brain.
Absolute threshold: minimum stimulus detected 50% of the time; JND: minimum detectable difference (50% of the time)
Weber's Law: JND is a constant proportion of the original stimulus (delta I / I = k)
Signal detection theory: performance depends on sensitivity (d-prime) AND response criterion (beta); know the 2x2 matrix (hit, miss, false alarm, correct rejection)
Sensory adaptation: decreased sensitivity to constant stimuli; pain receptors show minimal adaptation
Rods: periphery, low-light, black-and-white, high sensitivity; Cones: fovea, bright light, color, high acuity
Trichromatic theory: three cone types (retinal level); Opponent-process theory: antagonistic color channels (post-retinal); both are correct at different levels
Feature detectors (Hubel & Wiesel): simple, complex, and hypercomplex cells in V1 respond to edges, orientation, and movement
Place theory: high-frequency sounds; Frequency theory: low-frequency sounds; Volley principle: extends frequency theory
Gestalt principles: proximity, similarity, closure, continuity, figure-ground, common fate
Gate-control theory (Melzack & Wall): pain signals modulated at spinal cord; large fibers close the gate (reduce pain), small fibers open it
Bottom-up processing = data-driven (stimulus to perception); Top-down processing = concept-driven (expectations guide perception)
Broadbent's filter model (early selection): unattended info blocked before semantic processing; Treisman's attenuation model: unattended info turned down, not blocked — explains cocktail party effect
Deutsch-Norman late selection: all info processed semantically, selection at response stage; Lavie's perceptual load theory: high load = early selection, low load = late selection
Feature Integration Theory (Treisman & Gelade): preattentive parallel feature detection vs. focused attention for feature binding; illusory conjunctions occur without attention
Inattentional blindness: failure to see visible stimulus when attention is elsewhere (invisible gorilla); Change blindness: failure to detect large visual changes during disruption
Posner's spotlight model: spatial attention involves disengage (parietal), shift (superior colliculus), engage (pulvinar); right parietal damage produces hemispatial neglect
Two striking phenomena demonstrate the limitations of attention and conscious awareness:

Freud's wish-fulfillment theory: Dreams represent disguised expressions of unconscious desires. The manifest content (the dream as remembered) conceals the latent content (the underlying unconscious meaning) through dream work processes including condensation, displacement, and symbolization.

Activation-synthesis theory (Hobson & McCarley, 1977): Dreams result from the brain's attempt to make sense of random neural activation originating in the pons during REM sleep. The cortex synthesizes a narrative (the dream) from this essentially random brainstem activity. Dreams have no inherent meaning; they are the brain's "best guess" at interpreting noise.

Information-processing theory: Dreams serve a functional role in consolidating memories, processing emotional experiences, and integrating new information with existing knowledge. This theory is supported by evidence that REM sleep facilitates procedural learning and emotional memory processing.

Feeding: The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is the "hunger center" -- stimulation induces eating, and lesions cause aphagia (refusal to eat). The ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH) is the "satiety center" -- stimulation inhibits eating, and lesions cause hyperphagia (overeating) and obesity.
Particularly vulnerable to damage from chronic stress (cortisol is neurotoxic to hippocampal neurons), hypoxia, and Alzheimer's disease
Modulates memory consolidation: emotionally arousing events are remembered better because amygdala activation enhances hippocampal encoding
Bilateral damage (Kluver-Bucy syndrome) produces "psychic blindness" -- inability to recognize emotional significance of stimuli, hypersexuality, hyperorality, and flattened affect

Mammillary bodies: Part of the Papez circuit; relay information from the hippocampus to the thalamus. Degeneration occurs in Korsakoff's syndrome (thiamine deficiency) and contributes to anterograde amnesia and confabulation.
Subthalamic nucleus: Regulates the globus pallidus; lesions or deep brain stimulation here can reduce Parkinsonian symptoms

Substantia nigra: Located in the midbrain; its pars compacta produces dopamine that is sent to the striatum via the nigrostriatal pathway. Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons here is the primary pathology of Parkinson's disease.
Controls vital autonomic functions: breathing, heart rate, blood pressure, and digestive reflexes
